item.description:
Please join us for the next installment in our 2010|2011 "Bad News/Good News Movie Night Series, in which we will, in turn, immerse ourselves in some of the challenges of our time and then explore the solutions at hand. The first three films could be considered the dark side and the next set of films after the new year will no doubt inspire, educate and motivate. These films will be held the first Tuesday of each month on the campus of, and co-sponsored by, the University of New England.

In March we continue with some of the "good news" with a showing of A Forest Garden Year with Martin Crawford.  Martin is one of the premier agroforestry and "forest garden" experts in the world.  He is based out of the UK and rarely travels so this is about as close as we will get to Martin!  

In 1994 Martin Crawford started to plant a forest garden on a two-acre site on the Dartington estate in south Devon, and it is now largely mature. In this DVD he explains the principles of forest gardening, which is a kind of agroforestry. Forest gardens: are largely self-sustaining, containing a large number of very diverse species; provide a wide variety of fruits, nuts, edible leaves, medicinal plants and fibres; are self-fertilising by the use of specific plants which supply nutrients; use a large number of perennial crops, and are highly productive in terms of land use. The DVD was filmed over a ten-month period to show the forest garden in all seasons of the year.

Four-minute trailer here:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Ggwa5irxmg

Bonus: This film is less than an hour so if there is interest we will also show some selected clips from Geoff Lawton's "Establishing a Forest Garden" or "Forest Gardening with Robert Hart."


This will be a potluck (bring an appetizer/snack or beverage to share for a grazing-style meal) and your potluck kit (plate/utensils/cup/napkin). 6:30 potluck and 7:00 announcements and film. Discussion to follow.
item.how_to_find_us: Ludcke Autidorium is right on Stevens Ave and looks like a church.
item.why: it is a great way to learn about the concept of forest gardening (which is not necessarily gardening IN a forest, but gardening LIKE a forest).
